Description: A past cost settlement with Atlantic Richfield to reimburse the EPA for over $21 million of its cleanup costs at the Anaconda Smelter Site and the Warm Springs Ponds Operable Units.

The United States joined the five Gulf states in announcing a settlement to resolve civil claims against BP arising from the April 20, 2010 Macondo well blowout and the massive oil spill that followed in the Gulf of Mexico. This global settlement resolved the governments' civil claims under the Clean Water Act and natural resources damage claims under the Oil Pollution Act, as well as economic damage claims of the five Gulf states and local governments.
To resolve a Clean Air Act case involving eight refineries, BP agreed to spend $650 million to reduce emissions and pay a $10 million civil penalty.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: BP p.l.c. agreed to pay $525 million to resolve allegations that it misled investors while its Deepwater Horizon oil rig was gushing into the Gulf of Mexico by significantly understating the flow rate in multiple reports filed with the SEC.

Info Source: Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2006 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Description: Company knowingly or willfully submitted at least 21 false, misleading, or inaccurate royalty reports during 2009.
Agency: Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced that several subsidiaries of BP America Inc. agreed to pay a $426,500 penalty and ensure that more than $240 million in funds are secured to resolve violations of hazardous waste, drinking water and Superfund financial assurance requirements.

Agency: Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue
Notes: Source document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request to the agency.

Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: BP Amoco agreed to pay $32 million to resolve claims under the False Claims Act and administrative claims that the corporation underpaid royalties due for oil produced on federal and Indian leases since 1988.

Info Source: Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2002 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Description: BP Amoco Corp., Amoco Production Company, BP Exploration & Oil Inc., BP America Inc., Atlantic Richfield Company and Vastar agreed to pay the United States $20.5 million to resolve claims that the companies violated the False Claims Act by knowingly underpaying royalties owed on natural gas produced from federal and Indian leases.

BP Exploration (Alaska) Inc. was sentenced for failing to report the illegal disposal of hazardous waste on Alaska's North Slope. The U.S. District Court in Anchorage imposed the maximum criminal fine of $500,000 and ordered the company to establish a nationwide environmental management system costing an estimated $22 million to prevent future violations.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: BP Exploration Alaska, Inc. will pay a $25 million civil penalty and carry out a system-wide pipeline integrity management program as part of a settlement for spilling more than 5,000 barrels of crude oil from the company's pipelines on the North Slope of Alaska in 2006, the U.S. Department of Justice, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Department of Transportation's Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration announced.

Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: During the incident investigation, two violations were found. One was for discharging pollutants into Gulf waters and the other was for failure to maintain equipment in a safe manner which led to the discharge.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: During the course of a BOEMRE incident investigation, it was determined that the lessee did not ensure proper use of procedures for working aloft. An employee was working aloft without being secured to a fall protection system, which resulted in a fall and injury.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: During the course of a BSEE inspection, inspectors observed employees who failed to use fall protection around an unprotected open hole.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: During an on-site inspection, it was discovered that primary and secondary accumulator pumps were inoperable. Low fluid level for the fluid tank, low rig air, and low accumulator alarms were found inoperable.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: BP Exploration and Production Inc. agreed to plead guilty to felony manslaughter, environmental crimes and obstruction of Congress and pay a record $4 billion in criminal fines and penalties for its conduct leading to the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster that killed 11 people and caused the largest environmental disaster in U.S. history, Attorney General Eric Holder announced. The 14-count information, filed in U.S. District Court in the Eastern District of Louisiana, charged BP with 11 counts of felony manslaughter, one count of felony obstruction of Congress, and violations of the Clean Water and Migratory Bird Treaty Acts.

The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and BP Exploration and Production, Inc. announced a voluntary resolution of an investigation relating to the hiring of women by contractors providing temporary labor for the oil spill response in 2010.  The EEOC's investigation was based on concerns raised by several women in Louisiana and Alabama that certain contractors participating in the oil spill response did not consider them for the cleanup effort because of their gender.
Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced that BP North America Inc. has agreed to pay an $8 million penalty and invest more than $400 million to install state-of-the-art pollution controls and cut emissions from BP's petroleum refinery in Whiting, Ind. When fully implemented, the agreement is expected to reduce harmful air pollution that can cause respiratory problems such as asthma and are significant contributors to acid rain, smog and haze, by more than 4,000 tons per year.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Info Source: Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2001 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Agency: Occupational Safety & Health Administration corporate-wide settlements

Description: The U.S. Department of Labor's Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced that OSHA and BP Products North America Inc. have resolved 409 of the 439 citations issued by the agency in October 2009 for willful violations of OSHA's process safety management standard at BP's refinery in Texas City, Texas. Under the agreement, BP will pay $13,027,000 in penalties, and already has abated or will abate all existing violations by the end of 2012.
Agency: Occupational Safety & Health Administration corporate-wide settlements

Info Source: Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2006 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Description: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced the entry of a consent order in federal court settling charges brought against BP Products North America Inc. for manipulating and attempting to manipulate the price of TET propane in February 2004, for cornering the market for TET propane in February 2004, and for attempting to manipulate the price of TET propane in April 2003. The CFTC consent order required that BP pay a $125 million civil monetary penalty, establish a compliance and ethics program, and install a monitor to oversee its trading activities in the commodities markets. The consent order also recognized the payment of approximately $53 million by BP into a restitution fund for victims. A simultaneous deferred prosecution agreement with the Justice Department required BP America to pay a $100 million criminal penalty, plus $25 million for a consumer fraud fund.

BP Products North America, Inc. will pay a $210,000 penalty and implement an enhanced oil spill response program at its oil terminals nationwide, as well as a comprehensive compliance audit to resolve alleged violations of oil spill response regulations at its Curtis Bay Terminal in Maryland, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Department of Justice announced. The enhanced oil spill response program will help ensure that BP Product's oil terminals are better prepared to respond to oil spills that could impact human health and the environment.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Info Source: Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2006 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Private Litigation Case Title: Nelson v. BP Corporation North America

Description: Amoco Oil Co. agreed to pay $1.12 million in settlement of charges of soil and groundwater contamination from underground storage tanks at its service stations.
ARCO agreed to pay $250,000 in settlement of allegations its activity at the Summitville mine site contributed to environmental pollution.
Atlantic Richfield Co. and ASARCO LLC agreed to pay a total of $37 million in settlement of allegations they contaminated the Upper Blackfoot River with mine trailings.

BP paid a total of $4.9 billion to the states of Alabama, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas to resolve claims arising from the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. This was part of the larger $20 billion settlement that also involved the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-bp

BP agreed to pay $255 million to resolve a dispute with the state of Alaska related to money damages for oil production shortfalls caused by 2006 pipeline leaks and pipeline replacements in the Prudhoe Bay oilfield; $245 million came from an arbitrator's award.

BP agreed to pay $1,709,498 to settle charges of environmental violations after inspections by state environmental officials in 2007 revealed that at least three BP secondary containment areas in the Greater Prudhoe Bay field failed to meet size requirements set out by regulation.

BP agreed to pay an additional $1.5 billion to Mississippi to settle claims from the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill but this was later rolled into the $20.8 billion federal-state omnibus settlement; see https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-bp

BP agreed to pay a $10 million penalty to Indiana, Ohio and the federal government to resolve Clean Air Act violations. This was part of a larger $660 million settlement announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-bp-1

The California Attorney Generalannounced a $102 million settlement with BP Energy Company over allegations that it intentionally overcharged the State of California for natural gas that the State purchased under three successive contracts from March 2003 to August 2012.

Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Company: BP West Coast Products LLC, BP Products North America, Inc., and Atlantic Richfield Company
Description: The California Attorney General announced a $14 million settlement with BP West Coast Products LLC, BP Products North America, Inc., and Atlantic Richfield Company over allegations that the companies violated state laws regarding operating and maintaining motor vehicle fuel underground storage tank laws.
BP-ARCO agreed to pay $25 million in penalties and spend $20.8 million in improvements to settle alleged widespread underground tank violations at ARCO gasoline stations in California.
BP West Coast Products agreed to pay $4 million to the San Diego County District Attorney and the San Diego City Attorney to resolve environmental violations at its ARCO gas stations.
Info Source: ARCO to settle environmental suit, San Diego Union-Tribune, October 1, 2003 (via Nexis).
Contamination Settlement, City News Service, September 4, 2002 (via Nexis).

Description: Atlantic Richfield agreed to an $8 million settlement with the Orange County Distric Attorney to resolve allegations of groundwater contamination with the gasoline additive MTBE. The amount included $5 million to reimburse the county for legal costs and $3 million to study the extent of the contamination.

BP agreed to pay $230,000 in settlement of allegations it violated state regulations concerning Underground Storage Tanks, causing and failing to deal with groundwater pollution at two gas stations it owned in San Jose.

Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Atlantic Richfield entered into a consent decree with the Justice Department and the EPA requiring it to finance $150 million to clean up mining contamination in Butte and Walkerville, Montana.

Info Source: State slaps BP with fine; DEC: Oil company to pay up to $300,000 over leak detectors, Anchorage Daily News, June 5, 2004 (via Nexis).

Agency: Alaska Oil and Gas Conservation Commission
Alaska Oil and Gas Conservation Commission

Description: BP West Coast Products paid $2,542,000 in penalties for negligently supplying gasoline in violation of California reformulated gasoline regulations.  From February 4 to March 19, 2009, BP supplied approximately 64,000,000 gallons of fuel that exceeded the reported total aromatics from its Cherry Point facility.
BP agreed to pay $7.9 million in settlement of allegations it made false claims for reimbursement of costs to the Underground Storage Tank Cleanup Fund.
Agency: California State Water Resources Control Board

BP AMOCO CORP - TEXAS CITY REFINERY

Description: Atlantic Richfield and its parent BP agreed to pay a total of at least $13.5 million to resolve a class action alleging the company allowed a defunct mine in Nevada to leak harmful chemicals into water supplies of some residents of the city of Yerington. The total included about $6.1 million in payments to property owners, $900,000 for health monitoring and at least $6.5 million to pay for rerouting water supplies.
Private Litigation Case Title: Roeder et al v. Atlantic Richfield Company et al

Description: BP agreed to pay an estimated $7.8 billion to settle class action claims for economic loss, property damage and medical injuries in connection with the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster in the Gulf of Mexico.
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: Oil Spill by the Oil Rig "Deepwater Horizon" in the Gulf of Mexico, on April 20, 2010

Description: BP agreed to pay $19.5 million for its part in a case in which residents of Hartford, Illinois sued oil and pipeline companies for creating an underground petroleum lake that released harmful vapors into the air.

Atlantic Richfield agreed to pay an estimated $27.5 million to settle lawsuits that had been filed against it and Babcok & Wilcox alleging that radioactive dust from nuclear fuel facilities near Pittsburgh harmed local residents.
Private Litigation Case Title: Hall et al. v. Babcock & Wilcox Co. et al.

Description: BP Products agreed to pay $246,750 in settlement of a finding by IDEM that the company violated its air permit with excess particulate emissions.

Agency: New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection

Description: Settlement of fine over Title V permit regulations and Federal Protection of the Environment regulations.
Agency: South Coast (CA) Air Quality Management District

Description: BP Solar agreed to a settlement estimated to be worth more than $67 million to resolve class action litigation concerning defective solar panels.
Private Litigation Case Title: Allagas et al v. BP Solar International, Inc. et al

Description: BP was fined $100,000 for failures to prevent two leaks in the Olympic Pipeline after construction work as well as failures to complete safety assessments and to provide timely notifications.
Violation of requirement for market participants to comply with the ERCOT operating and reliability policies, rules, guidelines and procedures.

Agency: South Coast (CA) Air Quality Management District
South Coast (CA) Air Quality Management District

Description: Officials with the South Coast Air Quality Management District (AQMD) and BP West Coast Products LLC jointly announced  that they agreed to settle a lawsuit filed by the AQMD against BP and its predecessor, Atlantic Richfield Company (ARCO), regarding past air quality rule violations at the company's Carson, Calif., refinery. Under the terms of the settlement, BP will pay the agency $25 million in cash penalties and $6 million in past emissions fees. As part of the agreement, BP also agreed to provide  $30 million over ten years in community programs directed at asthma diagnosis and treatment, and $20 million in new refinery improvements aimed at reducing emissions.
Agency: South Coast (CA) Air Quality Management District

Description: Settlement of fines over gasoline dispensing and VOC emission regulations.
